text.headline: Permissiviness
text.text:
What is wrong with Open source?

A timeline about OSS permissiviness.

background.alt: The Great Linux World Map 2.0 by Dedoimedo

text.headline: ARPANET is born
text.text: The precursor to the modern Internet, ARPANET, is established, laying the groundwork for future open protocols.

text.headline: WWW is born
text.text: Tim Berners-Lee proposes the World Wide Web, enabling easy access to information and fostering a culture of sharing.

text.headline: The GNU Manifesto is published. FSF is born
text.text: Richard Stallman launches the Free Software Foundation (FSF) to promote free software principles, emphasizing user freedom and community collaboration.

text.headline: GPL is released.
text.text: The GNU General Public License (GPL) is released, establishing a strong copyleft license that requires derivative works to also be open source.

text.headline: Linux kernel adopts GPL
text.text: Linus Torvalds releases the first version of the Linux kernel under the GNU General Public License (GPL), establishing a model for collaborative software development.

text.headline: Rise of Permissive Licenses
text.text: The Apache Software Foundation (ASF) adopts the Apache License, promoting permissive licensing and fostering a new era of open source software development.

text.headline: InnerSource coined by Tim O’Reilly.
text.text: Tim O’Reilly coins the term 'InnerSource', describing the application of open source practices within organizations to improve collaboration and innovation.

text.headline: Web 2.0 emerges
text.text: Cobalt Networks builds Linux-based servers and thrives by contributing back enhancements while turning OSS into marketable hardware.

text.headline: Steven Weber publishes The Success of Open Source.
text.text: Steven Weber publishes The Success of Open Source, highlighting business opportunities in community-driven models.

text.headline: The GNU Affero General Public License (GNU AGPL) is published.
text.text: The GNU Affero General Public License (GNU AGPL) is published, extending the GPL to cover software used over a network, ensuring that users can access the source code of such software.

text.headline: Andrew Lampitt coins 'Open Core'.
text.text: Andrew Lampitt coins the term 'Open Core', describing a business model where a core product is open source, but additional features or services are proprietary.

text.headline: The decline of GPL starts.
text.text: Hadoop, OpenStack, Android, and others adopt permissive licenses. Mike Olson argues that Apache-style licenses foster mass adoption.

text.headline: Growth of the Open Core model
text.text: The Open Core model gains popularity, with companies like GitHub, Docker, and others adopting it to balance community contributions with commercial interests.

text.headline: MongoDB abused by Cloud hyperscalers.
text.text: MongoDB's original AGPL license protects network usage—but cloud providers begin exploiting OSS without contributing back.

text.headline: Movable Type Open Source initiative ends.
Redis adopts Apache 2.0 + Commons Clause
text.text: Redis Labs introduces the Commons Clause, a controversial addition to the Apache 2.0 license that restricts commercial use, leading to debates about open source purity.

text.headline: MongoDB adopts SSPL
text.text: MongoDB, Inc. introduces the Server Side Public License (SSPL), a controversial license that restricts cloud providers from offering MongoDB as a service without contributing back to the community.

text.headline: Confluent adopts Confluent Community License
text.text: Confluent, the company behind Apache Kafka, introduces the Confluent Community License (CCL), a license that restricts commercial use while allowing community contributions.

text.headline: Redis adopts RSAL
text.text: Redis Labs introduces the Redis Source Available License (RSAL), a license that restricts commercial use while allowing community contributions, similar to the SSPL.

text.headline: CockroachDB adopts BUSL
text.text: Cockroach Labs introduces the Business Source License (BUSL), a license that allows for community contributions while restricting commercial use, similar to the SSPL.

text.headline: Sentry adopts BUSL
text.text: Sentry, the error tracking platform, adopts the Business Source License (BUSL), allowing for community contributions while restricting commercial use.

text.headline: AWS launches DocumentDB
text.text: DocumentDB (MongoDB-compatible), prompting more SSPL/Elastic forks and AWS counter-moves (OpenSearch). Red Hat drops MongoDB from Fedora/RHEL due to SSPL.

text.headline: Elastic adopts dual license AGPL/SSPL
text.text: Elastic NV adopts a dual license model with the AGPL and SSPL, restricting commercial use while allowing community contributions.

text.headline: AI growth
text.text: Permissive licenses fuel AI training; massive data scraping becomes normalized across Google, Meta, OpenAI. IP & privacy protections struggle to keep pace.

text.headline: ChatGPT launches
text.text: OpenAI launches ChatGPT, a large language model that showcases the potential of AI but raises concerns about data privacy and ethical use.

text.headline: OpenAI adopts dual license Apache 2.0/CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
text.text: OpenAI adopts a dual license model with Apache 2.0 and CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, restricting commercial use while allowing community contributions.

text.headline: Redis forks Redis OSS
text.text: Redis Labs forks Redis OSS, creating a new version of the software that is not compatible with the original.

text.headline: Redis adopts dual license RSAL/SSPL
text.text: Redis Labs adopts a dual license model with the Redis Source Available License (RSAL) and the Server Side Public License (SSPL), restricting commercial use while allowing community contributions.

text.headline: GenAI disruption
text.text: Hyperscalers (MSFT/GitHub/OpenAI) form billion-dollar AI partnerships, cementing a downstream, permissive-dependent AI monopolization model.

text.headline: OSI publishes the Open Source AI Definition
text.text: OSI publishes the Open Source AI Definition, tackling the unique licensing complications of AI models and data.
